212. Boden, Madeleine A. (Mrs. Bernard D'Este)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Madeleine A. Bernard (Mrs. Bernard)
Address: 245 East Broadway, Vancouver 12, B.C.
Birthplace: London, England.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1907.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Lloydminster, Saskatchewan.
Where had you been living before that? Southgate, London, England.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2-3 times.
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? As often as necessary.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, rolled oats, salt, baking powder, lard, sugar, syrup, tea, crackers, and dried fruits such as apples, figs, peaches, currants, and raisins. Rice, whole & ground, corn starch.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (A very low grade marked XXXX. Later used "Five Roses".
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lbs. each.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour? Rarely.
Whole wheat flour? Never.
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?

Our groceries were always bought on credit or in exchange for farm products. As my husband almost always did the buying I do not remember anything about prices.

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 50 pounds.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.25.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.

Butter? Home made.

What was the price of butter? 10 cents per pound.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Chicken, rabbit, dry beef, bacon, pork, sheep cut of beef.

How did you get fresh meat from a butcher or farmer? Sometimes killed at home.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? As above, or rubbing with salt, brown sugar, salt, fat, or soaking in brine, boiling often.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Never heard of one.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds?

Prairie grouse, prairie chickens, pheasants, quail.

For how long? Six years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Once bought a box of herring for a box of salted cod.

Did you like it?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured.

Kinds?

I have a faint recollection of having frozen whitefish which was fairly good, and once had Winnipeg goldeyes which were a special treat.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? We grew our own.
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.
If not, where from? ............................................................
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1907-8
Potatoes 1907. Cabbage 1907. Carrots 1907. Onions 1907.
Turnips 1907. Beets 1907. My husband was growing his own vegetables 3 years before I came out from 1904.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ........................................

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, blueberries, raisins, currents or others)? We used quantities of figs which we bought by the bag (burlap). Fig pudding was our stand-by as a dessert.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.
Peas? ........... corn? ........... beans? ........... Saskatoons? .............
Other foods? .....................................................................................
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? First garden fruit 1912.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? Cuthbert Paepo.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? .................................
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? .................................
To what extent? .................................................................................
Did you make your own vinegar? ........................................................

Made jams & jellies from all wild fruits, strawberries, raspberries, high bush cranberries, gooseberries, cherries, Saskatoons, from 1907 to 1912. Have canned everything since leaving Saskatchewan.
When I first came to Canada had no knowledge of canning, had never heard of it. Even if I had known how to can vegetables, we could not have afforded the price of the necessary equipment. I used jam tins & wooden jam pans for my jams and bought a few jelly jars second hand.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ...From a spring...........................................

How far was this water from your home? ...About 2 mile......................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...By barrels........

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

This water was very alkaline & smell strongly of sulphur when first carried into the house. It was kept stored in two pailsful at a time & emptied into a barrel which stood in a corner of the kitchen. In winter we melted snow for washing. There was a rim of ice on the floor around the barrel, which did not thaw out all the winter.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made my own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... good ashes!

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Mostly Royal Crown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Hardwood from the bluffs.

Where did you get your fuel? In a hay rack. Green dry.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wood was very scarce in our district and my husband & his brother had to go for miles to haul enough logs for building shacks & stables etc. After I arrived any building had to be of lumber purchased in town. The first lumber bought after my arrival was for a new roof on our log shack. It was in June 1907 after the heavy rains had soaked through a 2 ply sod roof. The only dry spot in the shack was under the table where we put the flour & rolled oats etc. I cooked the breakfast with an umbrella over the stove & my hat & coat on.

Wood was used extensively in our district and not until husband and wife had to go forty miles to town for enough logs for building shacks, etc.

After purchased any building had to be of lumber purchased in town. The first lumber bought after my arrival was for a new roof on our log shack. It was June 1907, after the heavy rain had washed through and I flew down. The only dry place was under the table where we put the glass and rolled oats etc. cooked over an open fire over the stove or over heat.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast:
- Rolled oat porridge (made with skim milk)
- Dry salt bacon
- Eggs
- Bread, Butter
- Tea

Dinner:
- Prairie chicken (stuffed & roasted)
- Mashed apple turnip
- Boiled pudding with milk sauce
- Bread, Butter
- Tea

Supper:
- Rolled oat porridge made with milk
- Boiled eggs
- Stewed dried fruit
- Cake
- Bread, Butter
- Tea

This is a typical winter menu except the prairie chicken. In summer we had plenty of fresh garden vegetables. In winter the meal was usually steamed beef or rabbit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

We went out to a neighbour's to dinner the first Xmas. Had roast chicken & vegetables, also Xmas pudding & cookies sent from England.

The second Xmas invited neighbours & had the greatest luxury obtainable at that time, roast leg of lamb.

Following years raised our own turkeys and had turkey dinner with all the trimmings each Xmas.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never.

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   Head out to a neighborhood dinner. The food was hard to find, but we had a wonderful time. We invited neighbors and they quedded us with our own turkey and ham.

   Turkey dinner with all the trimmings called dinner.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Not until after we left the farm in 1913.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

One winter we had a stock of rabbits & kept them frozen for use as needed. I detested the job of skinning & cleaning them & could never eat any part but the foreleg though I am sure they were very good and were appreciated by those who did not have to prepare them.

One time my husband shot a Sandhill Crane. We thought it was a wild turkey. I went to a lot of trouble stuffing & roasting it. It was like tough old beef.
